description:
Epic Games seems to love saving its biggest collabs for the first season of each new Fortnite chapter, and that certainly has not changed in Chapter 7 Season 1--which has a battle pass that includes two classic and beloved movie characters, Marty McFly from Back to the Future, and Beatrix "The Bride" Kiddo from Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill.

In terms of name recognition, that's a pretty major pairing with at least as much name recognition as Godzilla and Hatsune Miku, which Fortnite kicked off Chapter 6 with a year ago. But if those folks aren't your speed, fortunately, there are six other skins on the Season 1 battle pass that you can enjoy.

Four of those skins are just regular humans, including a skater girl named Carina who has blue hair and a cast on her right wrist, who's sure to be an instant favorite. The pass rounds out wit
title: Fortnite Battle Pass Chapter 7 Season 1: All Skins And Other Rewards

description:
The last couple Fortnite Battle Royale islands have been based on real-life geography and ecosystems--Chapter 5 was Mediterranean Europe, and Chapter 6 was Japan. In Chapter 7, we've moved on to North America, and specifically the southwestern USA. The Chapter 7 map includes major locations based on Los Angeles, Las Vegas, San Francisco, and Area 51--in other words, it's Fortnite's San Andreas map.

It all starts in Battlewood in the southwest portion of the new island, which has its own version of the iconic Hollywood sign and streets lined with palm trees. Nearby, you'll find the sound stages of Sus Studios, and you can take a ride up the freeway--yes, this map has Fortnite's first four-lane highway--to visit the casinos of the Sandy Strip. And smack
title: Fortnite Chapter 7 Map For Season 1: All Map Changes

description:
Quentin Tarantino's fourth film, Kill Bill, was famously so long that it was split into two separate movies: Kill Bill Volume 1 and its sequel, Volume 2, released about half a year apart back in the early aughts. Soon, it'll celebrate a re-release, Kill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair, which stitches the movies back together and adds new scenes, too. But even a movie of its length has scenes left on the cutting room floor. Using Epic's Unreal Engine, Tarantino is closing a chapter of his career that's been more than 20 years in the making.

Totally separate from the new scenes found within The Whole Bloody Affair, The Lost Chapter: Yuki's Revenge is a roughly 10-minute scene built in Unreal Engine that brings together the Kill Bill series and, unexpectedly--or perhaps not--Fortnite. I recently attended the premiere of Yuki's Revenge at the packed Vista Theater in Los Angeles, alongside Tarantino and "The
title: Fortnite Made Quentin Tarantino's Long-Awaited Unfinished Chapter A Reality
